choices.text: Multiple codons decode the same amino acid
Single codon decode for two amino acids
First nucleotide in a codon is responsible for degeneracy
For a specific codon, only a single amino acid is indicated

questions.text: Degeneracy of the genetic code means:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Degeneracy in the genetic code is when multiple codons decode the same amino acid.

  • Some amino acids are encoded by several codons; for example, six different codons, UCU, UCC, UCA, UCG, AGU, and AGC, all specify serine.
  • Other amino acids, such as methionine and tryptophan, have a single codon.

Features of genetic codons:

  • The genetic code is usually universal from lower and higher eukaryotes, including humans, except for those of mitochondrial codes.
  • The reading of the genetic code during the process of protein synthesis does not involve any overlap of codons. Thus, the genetic code is non-overlapping.
  • Once the reading is commenced at a specific start codon, there is no punctuation between codons, and the message is read in a continuing sequence of nucleotide triplets until a translation stop codon is reached.
  • For any specific codon, only a single amino acid is specified; with rare exceptions, the genetic code is unambiguous, i.e., given a specific codon, only a single amino acid is indicated.

Single codon decode for two amino acids (Option B): For any specific codon, only a single amino acid is specified. A single codon never decodes for two amino acids during protein synthesis.

First nucleotide in a codon is responsible for degeneracy (Option C): In general, the third nucleotide in a codon is less important than the first two in determining the specific amino acid to be incorporated, and this accounts for most of the degeneracy of the code.

For a specific codon, only a single amino acid is indicated(Option D): For any specific codon, only a single amino acid is specified; with rare exceptions, the genetic code is unambiguous-that is, given a specific codon, only a single amino acid is indicated. However, it does not explain degeneracy.

choices.text: Code for the same amino acid
Do not code for any amino acid

questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Each codon consists of a sequence of three nucleotides; that is, it is a triplet code.
  • Three of the 64 possible codons do not code for specific amino acids; these have been termed nonsense codons.
  • These nonsense codons are utilised in the cell as translation termination signals; they specify where the polymerisation of amino acids into a protein molecule is to stop.
  • They are also commonly known as stop codons for their ability to "stop" translation.
  • The remaining 61 codons code for the 20 amino acids added to proteins cotranslationally.

choices.text: Charging of tRNA with amino acids

questions.text: The enzyme aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase is involved in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Nucleic acids do not have intrinsic affinity for the functional groups of specific amino acids.
  • Therefore, a protein is required to recognize both a specific amino acid and its corresponding tRNA.
  • A total of at least 20 specific enzymes are responsible for this dual recognition and attachment process.
  • These enzymes catalyze the attachment of the correct amino acid to its specific tRNA, a process known as tRNA charging.
  • This process is energy-dependent and occurs in two steps.
  • One specific enzyme catalyzes this reaction for each of the 20 standard amino acids.
  • These enzymes are known as aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases.
  • The amino acid is covalently linked to its tRNA via an ester bond.
  • This charged tRNA remains stable until the amino acid is incorporated at its correct position during polypeptide synthesis on the ribosome.

Dissociation of tRNA from ribosomes (Option A) occurs during translocation or termination, but it is not mediated by aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase. This is a function of elongation or release factors, not tRNA charging enzymes.

Termination of protein synthesis (Option C) is triggered when a stop codon is encountered in the mRNA. This involves release factors, not aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase. These release factors promote the release of the newly formed polypeptide chain from the ribosome.

Initiation of protein synthesis (Option D) involves initiation factors, the ribosome, and initiator tRNA (usually tRNAi^Met in eukaryotes), but not aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase. Although the initiator tRNA must be charged beforehand, the actual initiation step doesn't involve this enzyme directly.

questions.text: Substitution of the base can result in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Single-base changes (point mutations) may be transitions or transversions. In the former, a given pyrimidine is changed to the other pyrimidine or a given purine is changed to the other purine.
  • Transversions are changes from a purine to either of the two pyrimidines or the change of a pyrimidine into either of the two purines.
  • When the nucleotide sequence of a protein-coding gene containing the mutation is transcribed into an mRNA molecule, then the RNA molecule will, of course, possess the base change at the corresponding location.
  • Single-base changes in the mRNA may have one of several effects when translated into protein:
    • There may be no detectable effect because of the degeneracy of the code; such mutations are often referred to as silent. This would be most likely if the changed base in the mRNA molecule were to be at the third nucleotide of a codon. (Option A)
    • A missenseeffect will occur when a different amino acid is incorporated at the corresponding site in the protein molecule. This mistaken amino acid-or missense, depending on its location in the specific protein-might be acceptable, partially acceptable, or unacceptable to the function of that protein molecule. (Option B)
    • A nonsensecodon may appear, which would then result in the premature termination of translation and the production of only a fragment of the intended protein molecule. (Option C)

choices.text: Insertion of one nucleotide in DNA
Insertion of two nucleotides in DNA
Deletion of one nucleotide in DNA

questions.text: Frameshift mutation can occur due to all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Substitution (point mutation) replaces one nucleotide with another. It does not shift the reading frame and therefore does not cause a frameshift mutation. It may result in a silent, missense, or nonsense mutation instead.

  • Inserting one nucleotide into a DNA sequence shifts the mRNA reading frame during translation. This leads to distorted codon grouping, often producing a garbled amino acid sequence or premature stop codons. (Option A)
  • Similar to a single nucleotide insertion, inserting two nucleotides alters the reading frame (since it’s not a multiple of 3), causing a frameshift mutation and resulting in aberrant protein synthesis. (Option B)
  • Deletion of one nucleotide also causes a shift in the reading frame, leading to incorrect codon recognition, garbled protein sequences, and potential early stop codons. (Option C)

questions.text: All of the following are true sentences for P bodies, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Non-Translating mRNAs can form ribonucleoprotein particles that accumulate in cytoplasmic organelles termed P Bodies. P bodies are non-translating mRNA, never translated into protein.

  • P bodies are sites of mRNA metabolism. (Option B)
  • Over 35 distinct proteins have been suggested to reside exclusively or extensively within P bodies.
  • These proteins range from mRNA decapping enzymes, RNA helicases, and RNA exonucleases (5'-3' and 3'-5'), to components involved in miRNA function and mRNA quality control. However, incorporation of an mRNP is not an unequivocal mRNA "death sentence".
  • Indeed, though the mechanisms are not yet fully understood, certain mRNAs appear to be temporarily stored in P bodies and then retrieved and utilized for protein translation.
  • This suggests that an equilibrium exists where the cytoplasmic functions of mRNA (translation and degradation) are controlled by the dynamic interaction of mRNA with polysomes and P bodies.
  • Specific mRNAs can associate with the protein constituents that form P bodies, small dense compartments that incorporate mRNAs as mRNPs.
  • These cytoplasmic organelles are related to similar small mRNA-containing granules found in neurons and certain maternal cells. (Option C)
  • mRNAs, bound by specific packaging proteins are exported from the nucleus as ribonucleoprotein particles (mRNPs). (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following pharmacological agents inhibits protein synthesis due to its structural similarity with tyrosyl-tRNA?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Puromycin is a structural analogue of tyrosyl-tRNA.
  • Puromycin is incorporated via the A site on the ribosome into the carboxyl terminal position of a peptide but causes the premature release of the polypeptide.
  • Puromycin, as a tyrosyl-tRNA analogue, effectively inhibits protein synthesis in both prokaryotes and eukaryotes.

Tetracycline (Option A) prevents the binding of aminoacyl-tRNAs to the bacterial ribosome A site.

Chloramphenicol (Option B) works by binding to 23S rRNA, which is interesting in view of the newly appreciated role of rRNA in peptide bond formation through its peptidyl transferase activity.

Cycloheximide (Option D) inhibits peptidyl transferase in the 60S ribosomal subunit in eukaryotes, presumably by binding to an rRNA component.

questions.text: An operon, the unit of genetic expression, consists of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The operon model consists of related genes along with operator and promoter sequences.

  • Jacob and Monod in 1961 described their operon model in a classic paper.
  • Their hypothesis was to a large extent based on observations on the regulation of lactose metabolism by the intestinal bacterium E. coli.
  • The molecular mechanisms responsible for the regulation of the genes involved in the metabolism of lactose are now among the best-understood in any organism.
  • β-Galactosidase hydrolyses the β-galactoside lactose to galactose and glucose.
  • The gene encoding β-galactosidase (lacZ) is clustered with the genes encoding lactose permease (lacY) and thiogalactoside transacetylase (lacA).
  • The genes encoding these three enzymes, along with the lac promoter and lac operator (a regulatory region), and the lacI gene encoding the LacI repressor, are physically linked and constitute the lac operon.

choices.text: Influence only when located near the promoter region
Work when oriented in either direction, upstream (5') or downstream (3') from the promoter
Can work with homologous or heterologous promoters

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of an enhancer during the regulation of the β-interferon gene?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

An enhancer during the regulation of the β-interferon gene, work even when located at a further distance from the promoter.

  • They can exert their positive influence on transcription even when separated by tens of thousands of base pairs from a promoter.
  • Certain DNA elements facilitate or enhance initiation at the promoter and hence are termed enhancers. (Option A)
  • Enhancer elements, which typically contain multiple binding sites for transactivator proteins, differ from the promoter in notable ways.
  • Work when oriented in either direction, work upstream (5') or downstream (3') from the promoter. (Option C)
  • Can work with homologous or heterologous promoters. (Option D)
  • Other features of enhancers are:
    • Work by binding one or more proteins
    • Work by recruiting chromatin-modifying coregulatory complexes
    • Work by facilitating the binding or function of the basal transcription complex at the cis-linked promoter
    • One of the best-understood mammalian enhancer systems is that of the β-interferon gene.
      • This gene is induced on viral infection of mammalian cells.
      • One goal of the cell, once virally infected, is to attempt to mount an antiviral response to save the infected cell, then to help save the entire organism from viral infection.

questions.text: A defect in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator protein (CFTR) is responsible for Cystic fibrosis. CFTR is a:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cystic Fibrosis is due to Mutations in the Gene Encoding CFTR, a Chloride Transporter.
  • Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a recessive genetic disorder prevalent among whites in North America and certain parts of northern Europe.
  • CF is characterised by chronic bacterial infections of the airways and sinuses, fat malabsorption due to pancreatic exocrine insufficiency, infertility in males due to abnormal development of the vas deferens, and elevated levels of chloride in sweat (>60 mmol/L).
  • It is now known that mutations in a gene encoding a protein named cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator protein (CFTR) are responsible for CF.
  • CFTR is a cyclic AMP-regulated Cl− transporter.
